item.title: Best Prepaid Wireless Internet [current_date format="yy"]
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
Use our research to help you find the best prepaid internet deals.

The post Best Prepaid Wireless Internet [current_date format="yy"] appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Home internet is a must-have these days, but if you’re not interested in a traditional service contract or don’t want to deal with a credit check, consider looking at prepaid internet plans. With a prepaid internet plan, you won’t have the fastest internet speeds, but you’ll get flat-rate and pay-as-you-go pricing.

Many major internet service providers (ISP) offer prepaid internet plans alongside their standard internet plans. Let’s break down the biggest pros and cons when it comes to prepaid wireless internet plans.

Jump to:

  • Prepaid wireless internet plans
  • Prepaid mobile hotspot plans
  • What to look for

Interested in wireless internet service?

Enter your zip code below to see what ISPs service your neighborhood.

Prepaid wireless internet plans

ISPs like Cox and Xfinity have a handful of prepaid internet options available. Although they’re far from the best plans, you’ll get decent internet speeds and bundled hardware for an affordable price. Check out our internet speed guide and prepaid internet walkthrough if you’re shopping for internet for the first time.

Cox StraightUp Internet

Editorial rating (3.1/5)
Price:
$50.00/mo.
Download speeds:
Up to 100 Mbps
Upload speeds:
5 Mbps
Data cap:
1.25 TB
Contract:
N/A
View Plansfor Cox

Read full review

Not available in all areas. No term agreement. Same price for 2 yrs. Pricing, packages, and policies are subject to change, including when adjusting or removing services or equipment.
Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Cox StraightUp Internet is as straightforward as its name. With the plan, you’ll get 50 Mbps download speeds, a lengthy three-year price guarantee, and a bundled combo modem/Wi-Fi router.

Comparing Cox internet plans

Cox package Price Max download speeds Details
StraightUp Internet $50.00/mo. 100 Mbps
View Plansfor Cox

Fast $55.00/mo.** 300 Mbps
View Plansfor Cox

*For 12 mos. w/ 1-yr. term agrmt.
**No annual contract or cancellation fees.
Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

With StraightUp Internet, you’ll be paying $5 less than Cox’s base standard plan, and you’ll also avoid Cox’s third-year price hike (around $20) if you intend on sticking around for a while. Cox’s bundled equipment is also a nice add-on to help lower the sticker shock—you’ll have to pay extra for equipment on Verizon and Xfinity.

We’d recommend Cox StraightUp Internet if you’re looking for prepaid internet that’s easy to set up. Although Cox StraightUp costs more monthly compared to Xfinity’s prepaid plan, you’ll also get a longer price guarantee and a bundled modem (you’ll still need to pick up a router for Wi-Fi).

Visit our Cox internet review to learn more about StraightUp Internet and Cox’s standard internet plans.

Xfinity Prepaid Internet

Editorial rating (3.8/5)
Price:
$30.00–$45.00/mo.*
Download speeds:
Up to 200 Mbps
Upload speeds:
Up to 10 Mbps
Data cap:
1.2 TB
Contract:
N/A
View Plansfor Xfinity

Read full review

With Xfinity’s prepaid NOW Internet, you’ll get one week of internet service for $15 or pay $30.00–$45.00 for 30 days of service.

Package Price Download speed Upload speed Details
NOW Internet 100 Mbps $30.00/mo.* 100 Mbps 10 Mbps View plan
NOW Internet 200 Mbps $45.00/mo.^ 200 Mbps 10 Mbps View plan

* Restrictions apply. Not available in all areas. Limited to NOW Internet service, speeds up to 100 Mbps/10 Mbps. Actual speeds vary and are not guaranteed.
^ Restrictions apply. Not available in all areas. Limited to NOW Internet service, speeds up to 200 Mbps/10 Mbps. Actual speeds vary and are not guaranteed.

We’d recommend Xfinity Prepaid Internet if your house uses the internet only for emails or YouTube videos and if you’re interested in long-term budget internet service. Thanks to Xfinity NOW Internet’s flat-rate pricing, you’ll have the same bill every month and won’t be subject to Xfinity’s standard second-year price hike.

Check out our Xfinity Prepaid Internet review for a full breakdown of the service.

Don’t wanna be locked to a contract?

Read our best no-contract internet providers guide for the best internet plans that don’t require a one-year agreement.

Verizon Fios Prepaid

Editorial rating (4.1/5)

Read full review

Verizon’s Fios Prepaid packages are slightly slower than its standard Fios plans and—for the most part—you’ll be paying around the same price for slower internet download speeds. Verizon Fios has 300 Mbps, 500 Mbps, and 940 Mbps plans compared to Fios Prepaid’s 100 Mbps, 300 Mbps, and 940 Mbps packages.

Comparing Verizon Fios internet plans

View Plansfor Verizon

Consumer data usage is subject to the usage restrictions set forth in Verizon’s terms of service; visit: https://www.verizon.com/support/customer-agreement/ for more information about 5G Home and LTE Home Internet or https://www.verizon.com/about/terms-conditions/verizon-customer-agreement for Fios internet.

With Fios Prepaid, you’ll get far better download speeds compared to Xfinity or Cox thanks to Verizon’s fiber internet network. Fiber internet has faster download speeds and better reliability compared to cable ISPs.

We’d recommend Fios Prepaid if you need fast download speeds and don’t want to do a credit check for internet service. Check out our Verizon Fios review to learn more about Verizon fiber internet.

Sparklight’s new Pay As You Go plans are great alternatives to its regular, contract-free internet plans. With speeds ranging from 100 Mbps all the way up to 1 Gig, with affordable pricing to boot, we think Sparklight’s prepaid plans are some of the best out there.

Comparing Sparklight internet plans

Sparklight prepaid package Price Max download speeds Details
Pay As You Go 100 $35.00/mo. 100 Mbps
View Plansfor Sparklight

View Plansfor Sparklight

View Plansfor Sparklight

View Plansfor Sparklight

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Sparklight’s upload speeds are lacking compared to Verizon’s, but its download speeds are comparable—and its prices are even better bangs for your buck.

Hop over to our full Sparklight internet review to learn more about all of Sparklight’s internet offerings.

Prepaid mobile hotspot plans

Mobile hotspots can work in a pinch for prepaid wireless internet, but we wouldn’t suggest making them your home’s primary internet option.

4G speeds are much slower than most cable internet plans, and hotspot data caps are much smaller than those on major ISP plans. In most situations, you can expect maximum download speeds of around 20 to 30 Mbps on 4G. If more than a few people are using the internet at once, your internet connection will quickly choke.

Still, a mobile hotspot can be a potential option if you’re traveling cross country, need short-term internet access, or live by yourself and don’t want to sign up with traditional cable internet provider.

Best prepaid mobile hotspot plans

Provider Hardware price Data cap options Download type Details

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Interested in free internet?

Visit our free and low-income internet guide to learn more about free internet programs and see if you qualify for affordable internet service.

What to look for

Prepaid internet plans are designed for convenience, but they’re not without their limitations. Here’s what you need to know if you’re looking into prepaid internet service.

Download speeds

Generally, prepaid internet plans have middling download speeds. For example, Xfinity’s prepaid plans top out at 100 Mbps. At this speed, you’ll run into problems if more than two or three people want to use the internet at once. If you’re getting internet service for a whole family, you may need to upgrade to a non-prepaid plan.

Check out our internet speed guide if you need help figuring out your home’s ideal internet plan.

Contract-free internet

One of prepaid internet’s traditional advantages has been contract-free plans, but many ISPs have stopped using contracts that lock you in with an expensive early termination fee. It’s not a coincidence that Cox and Xfinity are among the few ISPs that still have contract internet plans.

Thankfully, prepaid plans don’t have the scheduled second-year price increase that’s commonplace for most internet plans. Cox even offers a three-year price guarantee on its StraightUp Internet plan. Still, if you’re looking for contract-free internet service, you don’t have to limit your search to prepaid internet plans.

Final take

Prepaid internet plans are convenient, but for better or worse, you’ll get what you prepay for. Don’t expect the best internet performance, but if you’re looking for the cheapest possible internet service that doesn’t require a credit check, you’ll want to look at a prepaid internet plan.

Methodology

We spent several days analyzing the top prepaid internet plans from major US ISPs. Our analysis focused on areas including cost, data caps, and availability from major retailers.

For more information on our methodology, check out our How We Rank page.

Related articles

  • Best No-Contract Internet Providers
  • Your Guide to Internet Speeds
  • Best Internet Deals

Prepaid wireless internet FAQ

Are there prepaid cards for wireless internet?

ISPs like Xfinity and Cox don’t offer cards for their prepaid wireless internet plans, but you can go into a store to extend your internet plan. But if you’re shopping for a prepaid mobile hotspot, you’ll be able to get a prepaid card from providers like Simple Mobile.

Is Xfinity Prepaid Internet wireless?

You can get wireless internet with Xfinity Prepaid Internet. Xfinity offers a modem/router combo that’ll provide wireless internet coverage in your home.

Is there any prepaid Wi-Fi?

Some providers, like Verizon and Xfinity, offer prepaid internet service that includes a Wi-Fi router for wireless internet service.

Can I use Xfinity Prepaid Internet anywhere?

You can use Xfinity Prepaid Internet anywhere within your home thanks to Xfinity’s combo router/modem. If you’re located within the range of your Xfinity router, you’ll have internet access. But if you’re outside of your house, you can’t use Xfinity Prepaid Internet. Xfinity Prepaid customers won’t have access to features like Xfinity’s Wi-Fi hotspot network.

The post Best Prepaid Wireless Internet [current_date format="yy"] appeared first on CableTV.com.

item.title: How to Get Cheap Internet (Including Free & Low-Income Options)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Oaks
item.description:
Your income bracket doesn’t have to limit your ability to access the internet. If your home needs a boost to cross the digital divide, take advantage of low-income internet options in your area.

The post How to Get Cheap Internet (Including Free & Low-Income Options) appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
How do I get free, low income, or cheap internet?

Your income bracket doesn’t have to limit your internet access. If your home needs a boost to cross the digital divide, take advantage of free, low-income, and cheap internet options in your area.

The Lifeline program can save you $9.25 to $29.25 monthly. You can combine federal programs like Lifeline with internet provider initiatives that start at $9.95 monthly for 100 Mbps download speeds.

Read on to learn more about how to get free internet service and other affordable internet plans.

Jump to:

    • Do you qualify for low-income internet?
    • Where to start with low-income internet
    • Affordable Connectivity Program
    • Internet provider discounts for cheap Wi-Fi
    • Free internet for families, students, and seniors
    • Lifeline discounts for free government internet service

Why you should trust us

Our internet experts have spent years keeping their ears to the ground for government assistant programs and internet provider programs that offer free or discounted internet for low-income households.

We strive to provide all the relevant links to help you get internet where you live, while also sharing our insight into which offers will get you the best bang for your buck, reliability, features, and customer satisfaction. Check out our How We Rank page for more information on how we compare providers.

Do you qualify for low-income internet?

Each of the low-income options we’ll discuss has different standards to qualify. But you’re a good candidate for most if your household makes less than or equal to 200% of the federal poverty guidelines or you already qualify for one or more government assistance programs:

  • National School Lunch Program (NSLP)
  • Public Housing (HUD)
  • Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
  • Supplemental Security Income (SSI)
  • Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF)
  • And more

But if you’re not eligible for low-income internet, don’t worry—we have other articles with recommendations for cheap internet service for your home and current internet deals. Check out lower-cost internet providers like T-Mobile 5G home internet and AT&T Fiber, or enter your zip code below to find nearby internet providers.

Don’t qualify for free or low-income internet?

Not to worry—there are still plenty of affordable internet plans out there to help you stay connected at a low cost. Hop on over to our Best Cheap Internet Packages and Senior Internet Plan guides to learn more.

Where to start with low-income internet

There are multiple options for affordable internet services. The best low-income internet option used to be the Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP), which offered qualifying households up to $30 per month off internet service (and up to $75 per month if you live on tribal lands). Unfortunately, Congress halted this program’s funding, and signups ceased as of February 7, 2024. Funding for the ACP ran out in May 2024, and the government internet program is currently inactive.

Due to the ACP ending, we recommend looking into two low-cost internet solutions that have been around a bit longer: Lifeline or individual internet provider initiatives.

Low-cost internet through Lifeline and internet providers

The first option is a government assistance program called Lifeline, which offers $9.25 per month off either internet or phone services to low-income households. Lifeline offers less savings than the ACP or most internet provider initiatives, but it’s better than nothing.

Second, there are a variety of internet provider initiatives with discounted monthly rates. ISPs like Xfinity and Spectrum have low-income internet programs with rates as low as $9.95 per month. Many are for low-income families with kids who qualify for the National School Lunch Program (NSLP), but the qualifications vary by provider.

At first glance, ISP low-income plans are a stellar deal, but not all homes qualify. Find out if you meet the requirements before you decide which option to go with.

Additional savings: If you share internet service with other low-income households or you live on tribal lands, Lifeline may come with extra discounts—up to $34.25 off internet per month.

Affordable Connectivity Program

At the end of 2021, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) introduced the new Affordable Connectivity Program (replacing the old Emergency Broadband Benefit program) to help low-income households afford internet for work, school, and healthcare needs. It came with up to $30 per month towards internet service for qualifying households (up to $75 per month for households on tribal lands).

Do I qualify for the Affordable Connectivity Program?

If you’re already participating in federal assistance programs or a low-income internet program, you’d likely qualify for the Affordable Connectivity Program. For eligibility, the FCC required that you or a member of your household meet at least one of the following criteria:

  • Your household income is less than or equal to 200% of the federal poverty guidelines.
  • You participate in federal assistance programs like SNAP, Medicaid, Federal Public Housing Assistance, SSI, WIC, or Lifeline.
  • You participate in tribal-specific programs like the Bureau of Indian Affairs General Assistance or Tribal TANF.
  • You qualify for the National School Lunch Program (NSLP).
  • You’ve received a Federal Pell Grant for the current award year.
  • You qualify for your participating internet provider’s existing low-income program.

How do I apply for the Affordable Connectivity Program?

Unfortunately, you can no longer apply for the ACP. The FCC has stated that February 7, 2024, is the last day for ACP applications, and the program has a projected end date of May 2024.

As long as you’re already in the ACP, you’ll still get your ACP internet discount for March 2024. According to the FCC, the ACP will provide a partial bill credit to providers for April if ISPs choose to accept it. But after May, the FCC expects the ACP to shut down fully.

Keep on reading to find out more money-saving alternatives to the ACP.

Cheap Wi-Fi for low-income homes

Many ISPs offer low-income internet plans, which are great alternatives to the ACP. These plans range from around $10 to $30 per month (although Verizon Fios’s could be up to $50) and typically offer around 50 to 100 Mbps download speeds.

Each provider has their own qualifications that must be met, so be sure to read on under the cut to find out which plan best suits your needs.

Internet Essentials from Comcast (also known as Xfinity) accepts the widest range of government programs to qualify for low-income internet.

To see if Xfinity or any of the other providers above offer internet near you, enter your zip code below. We respect your privacy, so we don’t save your zip code or share it with anyone else.

Internet Essentials from Comcast

If you live in an Xfinity area, you have access to the low-income program Internet Essentials. Eligible households get 75 Mbps download speeds with free in-home Wi-Fi and unlimited data for $14.95/mo. (plus tax). You’ll also have access to Xfinity Wi-Fi hotspots and get the option to purchase a low-cost computer.

To qualify for Internet Essentials, someone in your household must participate in one of the following programs: NSLP, HUD, veteran government assistance, senior government assistance, or Pell Grant. Head over to InternetEssentials.com to apply.

Access from AT&T

Access from AT&T offers up to 100 Mbps download speeds for $30.00 per month.

You can qualify for Access from AT&T with SNAP, SSI, or the National School Lunch program. Also, AT&T accepts households within as much as 200% of the federal poverty guidelines. There’s a helpful chart on the application website if you’re not sure whether you qualify.

Spectrum Internet Advantage low-income internet program

While Spectrum’s low-income internet program is higher priced than most others on our list, it’s also one of the few that offers aid to homes without K–12 children. It brings a lot more to the table too.

Spectrum Internet Advantage is solid, offering broadband speeds of 100 Mbps and a free internet modem with additional Wi-Fi service for $5 per month (internet providers normally charge $10 per month for Wi-Fi routers). To top it off, you won’t have to worry about data caps or contracts.

So if one or more of the people in your household are recipients of Supplemental Security Income, National School Lunch Program (NSLP), or Community Eligibility Provision (CEP) of the NSLP, you can fill out the Spectrum low-income internet application.

Astound’s Internet First

Astound offers Internet First for families and students in low-income households. If your household takes part in Internet First’s long list of qualifying public assistance programs, you can get internet access for only $9.95 a month—and your first 60 days are free.

Go to the Internet First website to apply for service.

Optimum Advantage Internet

Optimum offers their Optimum Advantage Internet plan, where eligible customers can get up to 50 Mbps internet speeds plus free installation, a free router, and no data caps for $14.99 per month.

To be eligible for the Optimum Advantage Internet plan, you or someone in your household must qualify or participate in NSLP, veteran government assistance, senior government assistance, or are a New York City resident attending a New York City public school. Click here to apply. 

Verizon Fios Lifeline

Rather than creating a new internet plan like many other companies, Verizon boosts the discount you’d normally get from the government-sponsored Lifeline Discount Program.

Lifeline, which we discuss in more detail below, offers $9.25 off internet service each month. Verizon Fios’s added discount brings that down even further, making its starting plan completely free.

Verizon Fios’s deal offers the fastest speeds on our list. With speeds this fast, you can easily hold video calls while other family members are on the internet, which is a great help if you’re working from home.

Affordable internet for families, students, and seniors

Free internet for low-income families and households

Many low-income internet programs focus on connecting students to valuable online resources, so they require that you have a school-age child at home.

If you don’t have any school-age children, there are other ways to qualify for low-income internet service. Anyone with Supplemental Security Income (SSI) can qualify for Spectrum Internet Advantage and Internet Essentials from Comcast.

Free internet for K–12 students

There are more internet-saving options available if you have kids at home and participate in the National School Lunch Program (NSLP), the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF), or Public Housing (HUD).

Each provider has a unique list of qualifying programs, so check the table above to see what they’re looking for.

Free internet for college students

If you’re a college student, look into free public Wi-Fi hotspots and internet services with free intro periods. Read our article “Cheap and Free Internet for Students” for an in-depth look at these options.

And if you’re a community college student in Colorado and Illinois, you may be able to get Internet Essentials from Comcast with documentation from your financial aid office.

One last thought: sometimes internet providers offer deals for students. Check out this month’s deals to see what’s available right now.

Free internet for senior citizens

If you qualify for Supplemental Security Income (SSI), you can get affordable internet with Access from AT&T, Optimum Advantage Internet, Spectrum Internet Advantage, Verizon Fios Lifeline, and Internet Essentials from Comcast.

To find out which of these providers is in your area, enter your zip code below:

Lifeline FCC internet subsidy for free government internet service

Lifeline is a government-sponsored program from the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). It works directly with internet providers to create lower monthly rates for folks who are near or below the federal poverty guidelines, take part in federal assistance programs, or live on tribal lands.

If your household income is less than or equal to 135% of the federal poverty guidelines or you participate in federal assistance programs, you can get a $9.25 per month discount on internet or phone service. Check Lifeline’s qualification page for more details.

And if you live on tribal lands, you can save even more per month, bringing you to a total of $34.25 off internet.

If you live with other people but don’t share money, you can also take advantage of Lifeline multiple times on your internet subscription.

The people you live with also need to qualify based on poverty guidelines or federal assistance programs, but as long as they aren’t considered part of your household by Lifeline rules, you can stack up the discounts for every person who qualifies.

Wondering what the Lifeline discount looks like with different providers? Take a look under the cut.

You might have noticed the final prices after Lifeline assistance are higher than those from ISP low-income programs. But don’t write Lifeline off—it’s a big help when providers in your area don’t offer their own initiatives. Lifeline makes internet accessible across the country, so it’s always an option if you qualify.

Not sure which of these providers are available where you are? Enter your zip code to see your options:

If you’ve decided the Lifeline program is for you, you can apply online, by mail, or through a local internet company. You can find all the details on the Lifeline website.

Apply for Lifeline

Get cheap or free government internet service today

The internet access plays a huge role in our daily life—from news to education to keeping in touch with your loved ones. With help from the ISP initiatives and the Lifeline program, we can all stay connected. Take advantage of these programs to get high-speed internet service at a price that works for your family.

Free and low-income internet service FAQ

How do I get internet with a low income?

The U.S. government offers discounted internet through the Lifeline program, and many internet providers have low-income internet plans for under $20 per month.

Can you get free internet?

When combining the $30 monthly discount from the Affordable Connectivity Program with any internet plan under $30, your internet would be completely free. However, new signups for the ACP have been halted starting on February 7, 2024. But check out similar government programs for free internet, like Lifeline, that can also potentially provide free or discounted internet.

How do I get free government internet?

There used to be several ways to qualify for the government’s Affordable Connectivity Program. If you had a household income of less than or equal to 200% of the federal poverty guidelines or qualified for SNAP, Medicaid, Lifeline, NSLP, or a Federal Pell Grant, you could apply. Unfortunately, new signups for the ACP have ceased starting February 7, 2024.

How do I get internet for $10 a month?

AT&T, Cox, Mediacom, and Xfinity from Comcast all offer low-income internet for about $10 per month. You’ll need to qualify for your internet provider’s specified government assistance programs to get these deals. Check out the provider-initiative chart to apply.

How fast is Comcast’s $10 internet?

Internet Essentials from Comcast (Xfinity) used to cost $10/mo., but the price increased to $14.95/mo. in 2025. We will say that with this price increase, Xfinity also increased Internet Essentials' speeds up to 75 Mbps from 50 Mbps and provided the plan with unlimited data, so it's still a great deal. Cox Connect2Compete still offers $10 internet, but only to households with at least one child in K-12 schools.

What internet can I get with food stamps?

If you have SNAP benefits (what folks commonly call “food stamps”), you can qualify for the Lifeline program.

Is the government giving free internet?

The Biden administration used to offer reduced-cost, or in some cases, free internet through the Affordable Connectivity Program, depending on household eligibility. It provided up to $30 monthly assistance towards your internet plan. However, new signups for the ACP halted starting February 7, 2024.

How do low-income families get computers?

Check out non-profit companies like Connect All and PCs for People that offer computer deals. Your internet provider may also have some affordable computer options. For example, Internet Essentials from Comcast gives customers the option to buy a computer for $149.99 (plus tax), and Cox Connect2Compete partners with PCs for People to offer a variety of cheap computers.

How do I get free government internet for seniors?

Lifeline is the main way that qualifying seniors can get free internet service from the government. Lifeline is a federal program that offers internet discounts of up to $29.25 per month if you're enrolled in a program like SNAP, SSI, or HUD. You can also potentially combine these with subsidized internet programs from internet providers to get free home internet.

Can college students get free internet?

Before February 2024, if you qualified for the Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP), you could get a big enough discount to get certain affordable internet packages for free. But if you missed the last ACP signup day of February 7, 2024, check out our suggestions for cheap and free internet for students.

Is Xfinity free for college students?

No, Xfinity isn’t free for college students, but it does offer deals for students who sign up online.

Does Spectrum offer discounts for college students?

Yes, Spectrum will often offer deals for college students. To see what promotions are currently active, check out our Spectrum deals page.

Does CenturyLink offer student discounts?

CenturyLink doesn’t usually offer discounts, but we keep an eye on things just in case—check out this list of internet deals to see if there are any CenturyLink promotions this month.

Is the Affordable Connectivity Program ending?

Earlier this year, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) announced that it is taking steps to wind down the ACP due to a lack of funding from Congress. This process included halting new signups after February 7, 2024, and ending the ACP as of May 2024. Learn more details about how this could affect you on the FCC's website.

Related articles

  • Best Cheap Internet Packages
  • Best Internet Deals
  • How Much Does Internet Cost?

The post How to Get Cheap Internet (Including Free & Low-Income Options) appeared first on CableTV.com.

item.title: Cox vs. AT&T Internet: Which Is the Best Internet Provider?
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
Get AT&T Fiber if it’s available in your neighborhood, but if you’re choosing between Cox or AT&T’s DSL plans, Cox’s internet network offers faster—but more expensive—service plans.

The post Cox vs. AT&T Internet: Which Is the Best Internet Provider? appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Best for cheap internet
Editorial rating (2.70/5)

Price: $55.00–$115.00/mo.
Download speeds: 300–2,000 Mbps
Upload speeds: 5 Mbps–2,000 Mbps

View plans
Compare top features

Price: $55.00–$115.00/mo.
Download speeds: 300–2,000 Mbps
Upload speeds: 5 Mbps–2,000 Mbps

Best for gigabit speeds
Editorial rating (4.00/5)

Price: $55.00–$155.00/mo.
Download speeds: 100–5,000 Mbps
Upload speeds: 1–5,000 Mbps

View Plansfor AT&T

Compare top features

Price: $55.00–$155.00/mo.
Download speeds: 100–5,000 Mbps
Upload speeds: 1–5,000 Mbps

Data effective as of post date. Not all offers available in all areas. 

Limited-time offer: Cox internet customers can save $15/mo. bundling with Cox Mobile on select internet plans. See if Cox internet and mobile are available in your area.

Get AT&T Fiber if it’s available in your neighborhood—the internet service provider’s (ISP) fiber plans are among the most affordable on the market. But if you aren’t able to get AT&T internet, Cox’s internet network offers alternative service plans—but they can be pricey.

AT&T vs. Cox pros and cons

AT&T

✓ Great fiber internet plans
✓ Better bang for your buck
✗ Inconsistent fiber availability

View Plansfor AT&T

Cox

✓ Decent entry-level internet plans
✓ An optional combo modem/Wi-Fi router rental
✗ Mediocre and expensive TV plans

View Cox plans

Jump to:

  • Head-to-head comparison
  • Plans and prices
  • Installation
  • Customer satisfaction
  • TV bundles

Ready to get a home internet provider?

Enter your zip code to confirm if AT&T and Cox are available in your town.

Compare AT&T and Cox head to head

Pricing Maximum download speed Maximum upload speed Details
AT&T $55.00–$155.00/mo. 100–5,000 Mbps 1 Mbps–5,000 Mbps
View Plansfor AT&T

Cox $55.00–$115.00/mo.** 300–2,000 Mbps 5 Mbps–2,000 Mbps View plans

Data effective as of post date. Not all offers available in all areas

Depending on your address, AT&T’s internet plans might offer better value than Cox’s. You’ll have the cream of the crop if your neighborhood has AT&T Fiber internet coverage, but if it doesn’t? Since, as of August 2023, AT&T no longer offers DSL plans, you’d need to settle for AT&T Internet Air. At the same price as AT&T’s old DSL plan and with nearly the same download and upload speeds, Internet Air offers up a solid alternative to DSL.

However, if you’re in a Cox area, we’d definitely recommend shelling out the extra money for Cox rather than settle.

Plans and pricing

AT&T internet plans

Package Price Download speeds up to Upload speeds up to Connection type Details
AT&T Internet 100 $60.00/mo. 100 Mbps 100 Mbps Fiber
View Plansfor AT&T

AT&T Internet 300
Best package 		$55.00/mo. 300 Mbps 300 Mbps Fiber
View Plansfor AT&T

AT&T Internet 500 $65.00/mo. 500 Mbps 500 Mbps Fiber
View Plansfor AT&T

AT&T Internet 1 Gig $65.00/mo. 1,000 Mbps 1,000 Mbps Fiber
View Plansfor AT&T

AT&T Internet 2 Gig $125.00/mo. 2,000 Mbps 2,000 Mbps Fiber
View Plansfor AT&T

AT&T Internet 5 Gig $155.00/mo. 5,000 Mbps 5,000 Mbps Fiber
View Plansfor AT&T

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.
Above pricing is after $10/mo Autopay & Paperless bill discount with a debit card or bank account; if using a credit card, then price is $5/mo more. Pricing includes Equipment Fee. Up to $99 install fee may apply, plus tax where applicable.

AT&T’s great fiber internet plans helped the provider earn a spot on our best internet providers list. At $65.00/mo. for the first year with up to 1,000 Mbps download speeds, AT&T Internet 1000 is one of AT&T’s top gigabit internet plans. We always recommend fiber-optic internet if it’s available because you’ll get best-in-class download and upload speeds that’ll easily support streaming 4K movies or online file uploads.

In cities with AT&T Fiber coverage, we’d recommend AT&T Internet 300. At $55.00/mo. for 300 Mbps maximum download and upload speeds, the mid-range plan has enough bandwidth for most households.

Since, as of August 2023, AT&T no longer offers DSL plans, we’d recommend you check out AT&T Internet Air. It costs about the same as AT&T’s old DSL plan—$60 per month—and with nearly the same download and upload speeds, Internet Air is a solid alternative to the now-defunct AT&T DSL. However, if you’re in a Cox area, we’ll always recommend cable over a DSL internet connection.

View Plansfor AT&T

Cox internet plans

Package Price Download speeds up to Upload speeds Details
StraightUp Internet $50.00/mo.** 100 Mbps 5 Mbps View plan
Fast
Best package 		$55.00/mo. 300 Mbps 300 Mbps View plan
Go Even Faster $80.00/mo. 500 Mbps 500 Mbps View plan
Go Super Fast $95.00/mo. 1,000 Mbps 1,000 Mbps View plan
Go Beyond Fast $115.00/mo. 2,000 Mbps 2,000 Mbps View plan

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.
Available in select markets only. No annual contract or cancellation fees.
**Not available in all areas. No term agreement. Same price for 2 yrs. Pricing, packages, and policies are subject to change, including when adjusting or removing services or equipment.

Cox’s prepaid StraightUp Internet plan is a decent option for affordable cable internet service. With download speeds of 100 Mbps for $50.00/mo., it’ll be a great fit if you just want to send out emails or watch YouTube videos.

Cox’s faster plans are more of a mixed bag. With download speeds of up to 300 Mbps, Fast is going to be a decent starter plan for most households. For a mid-sized family of average internet users, we usually recommend an internet plan with download speeds between 100 to 300 Mbps.

But if you want to upgrade, Cox’s other options are a $80.00/mo. 500 Mbps plan, a $95.00/mo. 1,000 Mbps plan, and a new $115.00/mo. 2,000 Mbps plans. All three plans will be more than fast enough for a large household of frequent internet users, but compared to AT&T Fiber, none are a great deal.

Still, Cox’s cable internet network has more consistent availability than AT&T’s fiber internet networks. Whether you’re in Arizona or Louisiana, you’ll still get nearly all of Cox’s internet plans. But with AT&T, you might get AT&T Fiber—or not.

Ultimately, we’d recommend Fast for most Cox customers. Although it’s not the fastest or most affordable mid-tier internet plan, it’ll still be fast enough for two- to four-person households that enjoy Netflix sessions and occasional video calls.

View Cox plans

Cox vs. AT&T installation

Fee AT&T Cox
Installation Up to $99.99 Varies by region
Self-installation Free Free
Hardware rental $10.00/mo. (required) $13.00/mo. (optional)

AT&T and Cox have hefty installation fees in the fine print, but it’s easy to avoid the charges. Depending on your house’s wiring setup, you can avoid AT&T’s installation fee by ordering service online. If you’re okay with installing your own modem and Wi-Fi router, Cox offers free installation kits.

Cox earns the win over AT&T thanks to its open hardware policy. Although Cox offers a combo Wi-Fi router/modem for $13.00 a month, you can also use your own modem and wireless router for free. We like this flexibility because you’ll save in the long-term by buying your own equipment and avoiding rental fees.

But on AT&T’s plans, you’ll have to pay a mandatory $10.00 monthly equipment fee for AT&T’s combo router/modem, and there’s no way to use your own equipment. AT&T’s leased equipment can be convenient if you’d prefer not to troubleshoot or buy your own hardware, but we suggest avoiding rental fees whenever possible.

Buying your own internet equipment?

Read our wireless router and combo cable modem/router guides for our top hardware picks.

Customer satisfaction

AT&T earned 7th place in our 2024 internet customer satisfaction survey rankings compared to Cox’s 14th-place finish. AT&T largely maintained its high standing throughout our survey, while Cox rotated in the middle tier with providers like Spectrum and CenturyLink.

Trying to get an internet and TV bundle?

Enter your zip code below to see your TV and internet bundle options.

Cox vs. AT&T TV bundles

Cox TV plans

Package Price* Channel count
Cox TV Starter $71.00/mo. 75+ View plans
Cox TV Preferred $125.00/mo. 140+ View plans
Contour TV Ultimate $162.00/mo. 250+ View plans

*No Term Agreement. 2 Year Price Guarantee. Pricing, packages, and policies are subject to change, including when adjusting or removing services or equipment. Prices do not include applicable taxes, surcharges, usage-based charges (such as data, toll usage, pay-per-use service), and other fees. After any promotional period, regular rates apply (see www.cox.com).

To get any basic cable channels on Cox, you’ll have to spring for the provider’s $125.00/mo. Cox TV Preferred package. On competing TV packages in the same price range, you’d typically be getting premium channels like Paramount+ with SHOWTIME®.

Cox TV Preferred has a decent channel lineup, but the only ways to get popular networks like Disney XD and DIY Network on Cox is to upgrade to Contour TV Ultimate for $162.00/mo. or pay for Cox’s à la carte channel packs ($10.00 to $12.00 per month). With Cox TV Preferred, you’re paying premium cable prices for a basic cable channel lineup.

AT&T, as of January 2024, no longer offers bundles with Stream with DIRECTV like they have in the past. Even if they don’t offer the bundles anymore, we’d still recommend you go for DIRECTV STREAM over Cox’s TV plans. With Stream with DIRECTV’s ENTERTAINMENT ($89.99/mo.) and CHOICE ($94.99/mo.) packages, you’ll get channels like Nick Jr. and B1G Network for far less than Cox offers them. Cox’s lone advantage is Contour TV Ultimate, which includes every premium and basic cable channel for less than Stream with DIRECTV’s PREMIER package.

Spring for Cox’s Contour TV Ultimate package if you want to load up on premium and basic cable channels. But for most households, Stream with DIRECTV offers stronger basic cable lineups for less per month compared to Cox—just remember that you can no longer do an official bundle with AT&T internet.

Is Cox or AT&T internet more worth it?

If your neighborhood gets AT&T Fiber service, we’ve got an easy recommendation: get AT&T and don’t second-guess it.

But if you’re stuck between Cox and AT&T Internet Air, our recommendation comes with a few asterisks.

AT&T Internet Air offers some value if you’re in a neighborhood with at least a 75 Mbps plan and you don’t need the best internet service. But if your household has more than a few regular internet users, your best options will be either Cox’s faster internet packages or looking for other ISPs in your area.

Ready to look for an internet provider?

Enter your zip code to see what ISPs operate in your neighborhood.

AT&T vs. Cox FAQ

Which is better: Cox or AT&T internet?

AT&T Fiber is better than Cox Communications’s internet plans if it’s available in your area.

Is AT&T or Cox cheaper?

AT&T generally has cheaper internet plans than Cox, but it depends on the package and your location.

What internet is better than AT&T?

AT&T Fiber can easily compete with other fiber internet providers like Google and Verizon Fios.

Is Cox internet any good?

Cox has great basic internet packages and fast internet speeds, although its prices can be higher compared to other ISPs.

Why you should trust us

We analyzed data including our annual customer customer satisfaction survey and provider terms of service, rating Cox and AT&T on bang for your buck, reliability, and features. Then we matched up both companies head to head to give a clearer picture of their strengths and weaknesses. For more information on our methodology, check out our How We Rank page.

Related articles

  • AT&T Internet Review
  • Cox Internet Review
  • Best Internet Providers

The post Cox vs. AT&T Internet: Which Is the Best Internet Provider? appeared first on CableTV.com.

item.title: What You Need to Know Now That CenturyLink Is Brightspeed
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
What’s the deal with Brightspeed and CenturyLink? Read our guide to get up to speed on the relationship between both ISPs.

The post What You Need to Know Now That CenturyLink Is Brightspeed appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Internet mergers are a rarer occurrence these days, so CenturyLink customers could be forgiven for being surprised by their provider switcheroo. Brightspeed, a new provider based out of North Carolina, launched its network by purchasing a chunk of CenturyLink’s old network across the U.S.

Here’s what you need to know if you’re a new Brightspeed customer who was formerly a CenturyLink subscriber.

Looking for better internet service?

Enter your zip code below to see internet service providers in your area.

Are CenturyLink and Brightspeed the same company?

Brightspeed and CenturyLink aren’t the same company, but Brightspeed wouldn’t be here if it weren’t for CenturyLink. Back in 2022, private equity firm Apollo Global Management dropped $7.5 billion to acquire parts of Lumen’s internet network across 20 states. (Lumen is the parent company of CenturyLink and Quantum Fiber.)

Soon after, Apollo used this network to launch Brightspeed. As with CenturyLink, Brightspeed offers fiber and DSL internet service for new customers.

Are Quantum Fiber and Brightspeed the same company?

Brightspeed’s internet adoption process also applies to Quantum Fiber, Lumen’s spinoff brand for its fiber internet services.

If you were a Quantum Fiber customer in an area that Lumen sold to Brightspeed, your internet service would change entirely from Quantum to Brightspeed. You’ll still be on the same fiber network you were as a Quantum customer, but Brightspeed will take over things like network management, billing, and customer support.

What are the biggest differences between Brightspeed and CenturyLink?

As a relatively new internet provider, Brightspeed has its share of differences from CenturyLink. Whether you’re a longtime CenturyLink customer or a new Brightspeed shopper, here’s what you need to know about each provider’s fine print.

Internet plan prices

Former CenturyLink or Quantum Fiber subscribers have lucked out, as you’ll be grandfathered into your old plan on Brightspeed—your plan won’t change as part of the move.

New Brightspeed customers have a few more options compared to CenturyLink, as the ISP offers a budget-friendly 200 Mbps plan alongside 2 and 8 Gbps plans where available. Brightspeed’s non-deal pricing on its budget plans is slightly higher than CenturyLink, but its 1 Gig plan is much cheaper than the competition.

Plan Brightspeed* CenturyLink*
500 Mbps $39.99/mo. $50.00/mo.
1 Gbps $49.99/mo. $75.00/mo.

* Base pricing.

Equipment

In most cases, your CenturyLink modem or combo gateway will work identically on Brightspeed. Brightspeed suggests swapping out your hardware if it’s more than a few years old, but it likely won’t cost you much.

As with CenturyLink, Brightspeed includes a free combo modem/Wi-Fi router with every fiber internet plan, so you won’t need to spring for extra hardware. But if you’re on a DSL plan, you’ll either need to lease a combo gateway ($15/mo.), purchase a Brightspeed model ($200), or buy your own.

Customer service

Brightspeed took over CenturyLink and Quantum Fiber’s old customer account and tech support portal, so expect a slight adjustment compared to your old CenturyLink setup. However, former CenturyLink and Quantum customers can still use their old login credentials to access their accounts.

As with CenturyLink, Brightspeed doesn’t have physical retail locations for troubleshooting and equipment dropoffs. But Brightspeed maintains a sizable online support hub and offers a dedicated phone chat team through its Total Home Tech Support service for an additional $10 monthly.

Why you should trust us

Our internet experts have spent more than a year analyzing Brightspeed internet plans and their service. As part of our main Brightspeed internet review, we evaluated Brightspeed’s internet performance, service details, and online customer feedback. All provider recommendations and insight come from this first-hand experience, which we cross-referenced with CableTV.com’s existing internet provider coverage.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Related articles

  • Brightspeed Internet Review
  • Brightspeed Availability Guide
  • Best Fiber Internet Providers

The post What You Need to Know Now That CenturyLink Is Brightspeed appeared first on CableTV.com.

Read our AT&T deals guide to find out about the best AT&T offers.

View Plansfor AT&T

What to look for in internet packages and deals

When you’re looking for internet deals, here’s what you’ll need to know to make sure you get the biggest savings and fastest download speeds.

Prepaid gift cards

Depending on your internet provider, it’ll usually take between two to three months before you get your prepaid cash card. Oftentimes, the cards are sent through a third-party company and won’t come directly from your internet provider. Make sure to mark in your calendar when your card should arrive and be ready to give your internet provider a call if you don’t spot the card in your inbox.

Price

Internet providers throw out deals like free months and cash cards to get your foot in the door, but the best providers give you a reason to stick around. Make sure that your internet price is guaranteed for at least a year and won’t drastically increase after the 12-month mark.

There are a ton of internet providers that also have special offers for low-income folks, students, and seniors. Check out our guide to free and low-income internet to get the low down.

Download speeds

When you’re deciding on an internet plan, you don’t want to overpay or underpay for a package with download speeds that don’t fit your home’s internet needs. Typically, we recommend sub-100 Mbps internet plans only if your home has light internet requirements like checking emails. If your household regularly streams 4K video and takes Zoom calls, we’d suggest upgrading to a plan with at least 300 Mbps download speeds.

Prepaid internet

If you’re looking for budget and no-contract internet service, consider a prepaid internet plan from a provider like Cox and Xfinity. Prepaid internet plans generally offer slow download speeds of less than 100 Mbps, but you’ll pay a flat rate and won’t have a price increase after your first year of service.

Student and military discounts

Some ISPs offer discounts for subscribers who are students, teachers, or military service members. For example, Xfinity offers a gift card for veterans or active service members. Visit your ISP’s website to confirm if you qualify for any potential discounts.

Numerous ISPs also offer affordable low-income internet plans for qualifying customers. Check out our low-income internet guide to learn more about these programs.

Find the best internet deals

Internet deals may seem like gimmicky promotions, but if you take advantage of them right, you can save a lot. Verizon Fios and AT&T offer great packages and fiber internet speeds for new customers, while Xfinity and make the sign-up process a breeze for students and new customers.

When you’re shopping for an internet deal, look for providers who offer bonuses like prepaid cards, free months of service, or free subscriptions to services like Max. If the deals above don’t scratch your money-saving itch, check out the best cheap internet packages we recommend.

Curious which internet service providers are in your neighborhood?

Enter your zip code below to see what ISPs are available in your area:

Internet deals and packages FAQ

What company has the best internet deals?

Verizon’s buyout deal gets you the most for your money, and it’s flexible. When purchasing Verizon Fios internet service, Verizon will help you escape your current internet service provider. It’ll take some work on your part (including filling out an online form), but the up to $500 contract buyout is worth it.

How do I find the best internet deals?

Check back to this page whenever you want to get a special offer with your internet service. We’ll keep everything up to date, so make sure you drop by again.

Are there any satellite internet deals right now?

Depending on your area, Hughesnet may offer deals that include monthly savings and gift cards for your internet plan.

Who has the cheapest and best internet service?

Xfinity, Verizon Fios, and AT&T offer the cheapest internet plans with download speeds of at least 100 Mbps. Check out our cheap internet guide to learn more about affordable internet packages.

Who has the best deal on home internet?

Verizon, Xfinity, Astound, AT&T, and Spectrum offer some of the best deals on home internet because they include add-ons like free gift cards, hardware, and subscription services.

What company offers the best Internet service?

Google Fiber, Verizon Fios, T-Mobile, AT&T, and Xfinity all landed on our best internet providers list thanks to their value and service plans. Check out our full best internet providers guide for more information.

Why you should trust us

Our monthly promotions are tracked down by a rabid team of data specialists so that you get the most accurate information possible. We also put our editorial know-how to the test by comparing the deals and top packages from nationwide providers so you don’t have to. To learn more about our methods, check out our How We Rank page.

Related articles

  • Best Fiber Internet Providers
  • Best No-Contract Internet Providers

item.title: NFL Schedule This Week: Your TV Guide to Every Week 6 Game
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
Get ready for game day with our NFL TV schedule guide. We update this page weekly during the NFL regular season, so you can easily find kick-off times and channel listings for the week’s biggest matchups.

The post NFL Schedule This Week: Your TV Guide to Every Week 6 Game appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
And just like that, no undefeated NFL teams remain. Last week, both the Buffalo Bills and the Philadelphia Eagles took their first losses of the season. If you’re a fan of one of those teams, there’s absolutely no need to panic. We’re just seeing the parity of the league in full effect. (Though New York Jets fans should definitely be worrying, as Gang Green has yet to pick up a win.)

Week 5 was absolute chaos, reminding me why I bother watching this league every week. We all saw the Kansas City Chiefs lose a heartbreaker thanks to a 99-yard pick-six from the Jaguars. And how about the Titans, who had no business beating the Cardinals but pulled it off because an opponent literally dropped a recovered interception short of the goal line? It proves you can never truly relax until the final whistle blows.

Now, we charge into Week 6, which is packed with more excitement. We’ve got an international showdown, plus a Monday night doubleheader tailor-made for your multiview setup. To help you get ready, I’ve laid out the complete TV schedule below.

Jump to:

  • CTV’s NFL Game of the Week
  • NFL TV schedule this week

Bookmark this page. Stay updated with the NFL schedule all season by saving this page to your web browser.

Find the best TV provider for football

Enter your zip code below to see the top-ranked TV providers available in your area.

CableTV.com’s NFL Game of the Week

San Francisco 49ers at Tampa Bay Buccaneers | CBS, Paramount+, NFL Sunday Ticket

Coverage begins Sunday, October 12, at 4:25 p.m. ET: This is a fantastic pairing of two 4–1 teams trying to solidify their place among the NFC’s elite. The San Francisco 49ers are coming off a gritty overtime win, but are dealing with a ton of injuries, including to star quarterback Brock Purdy. On the other side, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers are riding high after another dramatic, last-minute victory. But they know they can’t keep winning by the skin of their teeth.

I’ll be watching to see if the 49ers’ injury-riddled defense can handle the red-hot Baker Mayfield. He’s been playing sensational football and has a new favorite target in rookie sensation Emeka Egbuka, who’s quickly becoming one of the league’s most explosive receivers. For the Niners, the big question is whether they can get their running game going, as they are one of the only teams in the last 90 years to start 4–1 without a rushing touchdown.

As the 49ers deal with so many injuries, I’m leaning toward the Buccaneers to get the dub at home. This is a marquee late-afternoon game on CBS and Paramount+. It’ll air to a large portion of the country, but out-of-market viewers will need NFL Sunday Ticket to catch the action.

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest must-watch sporting events, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

NFL TV schedule this week

Every NFL regular-season game airs nationally except for the regional Sunday afternoon matchups on CBS and FOX. If you want live access to out-of-market games, you’ll need NFL Sunday Ticket or NFL RedZone’s whip-around coverage. All local and primetime games stream live on NFL+ for mobile device users.

Below is the complete list of NFL Week 6 matchups. You can also check out 506 Sports’ broadcast map to see which Sunday games will air in your region.

Game Date Time (ET) Channels
Philadelphia Eagles at New York Giants Thursday, Oct. 9 8:15 p.m. Amazon Prime Video
Denver Broncos at New York Jets (in London) Sunday, Oct. 12 9:30 a.m. NFL Network
Los Angeles Rams at Baltimore Ravens Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. FOX
Dallas Cowboys at Carolina Panthers Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. FOX
Arizona Cardinals at Indianapolis Colts Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. FOX
Seattle Seahawks at Jacksonville Jaguars Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. FOX
Los Angeles Chargers at Miami Dolphins Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Cleveland Browns at Pittsburgh Steelers Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
New England Patriots at New Orleans Saints Sunday, Oct. 12 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Tennessee Titans at Las Vegas Raiders Sunday, Oct. 12 4:05 p.m. FOX
San Francisco 49ers at Tampa Bay Buccaneers Sunday, Oct. 12 4:25 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Cincinnati Bengals at Green Bay Packers Sunday, Oct. 12 4:25 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Detroit Lions at Kansas City Chiefs Sunday, Oct. 12 8:20 p.m. NBC, UNIVERSO, Peacock
Buffalo Bills at Atlanta Falcons Monday, Oct. 13 8:15 p.m. ESPN, ESPN Deportes
Chicago Bears at Washington Commanders Monday, Oct. 13 8:15 p.m. ABC

Data effective as of post date. CBS and FOX games air in select markets.

Don’t miss your local NFL team in action

Enter your zip code below to find the best TV plans in your area that offer local and primetime NFL channels.

NFL Schedule This Week FAQ

What week is it in the NFL?

It’s currently Week 6 of the 2025 NFL regular season. After a wild Week 5 that saw both the Eagles and Bills lose, the playoff picture remains as wide open as ever.

Which NFL teams have a bye this week?

The Houston Texans and Minnesota Vikings are on a bye in Week 6. The Vikings are likely happy for the rest after their back-to-back games in Europe.

Who is the best team in the NFL today?

For the first time this season, there’s a new team at the top of the NFL Power Rankings. After impressive wins over the Ravens and Bengals, the Detroit Lions (4–1) have leapfrogged the Eagles and Bills to claim the No. 1 spot.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, has been writing and refining this weekly NFL schedule guide since the 2022 season. Each week, he reviews the official league schedule and cross-references it with every broadcast partner. This process assures the channel listings for each matchup—including Spanish-language and alternate broadcasts—are always accurate.

Taylor’s “Game of the Week” selection comes from that hands-on experience, as he watches multiple games in their entirety every game week. His pick is a blend of on-field analysis (team performance, playoff stakes) and off-field expertise (broadcast accessibility). That dedicated, hands-on experience is what gives this TV guide a true fan’s perspective.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about CableTV.com and the methods we use.

Game day starts here!

  • How To Watch Sunday Night Football
  • How To Watch Thursday Night Football

It’s hard to find a good TV and internet bundle for $100 these days—many companies offer cheap plans, but are often only bundling a bare-bones local TV package with their internet. As always, we never recommend paying a cable company a monthly rate for local TV, since you could just buy your own OTA antenna for a one-time payment.

Luckily though, WOW! is currently offering budget options that actually provide the channels you want, thanks to a bundle with YouTube TV. You’ll notice this is the second bundle with YouTube TV we have on this page—it’s just hard to deny the appeal of the best live TV streaming service currently on the market. (Also, we know this bundle is three bucks more than $100. Forgive us.)

If internet speed is more important to you than keeping your price right at $100, a good upgrade is the WOW! Internet 600 Mbps + YouTube TV bundle, where you’ll get double the download speeds for just $15 more a month.

WOW! Internet 300 Mbps + YouTube TV deals

  • Save $10/mo. on YouTube TV for 1 year when you bundle with WOW! Internet
  • Refer your friends to WOW! and you’ll both get a $100 Visa® Reward Card after they sign up
View Plansfor WOW!

Prefer to cut the cord?

Cable TV and internet bundles aren’t for everyone, of course, and cutting the chord is a great option for a lot of our readers. Check out our live TV streaming services guide to learn more about services like YouTube TV, Hulu + Live TV, and Fubo.

What to look for in TV and internet packages and deals

If you’re more of the DIY-type, it’s not too hard to find a good TV and internet package. Here’s what you should look for when you strike out on your own.

Price

We recommend you skip out on any packages that only offer local TV—you can get that cheaper with a digital antenna. Without those local TV plans, expect your cheapest TV and internet bundles to start at around $75 per month.

The only time you should pay more than $150 a month is when you get zooming fast download speeds (over 500 Mbps) plus a hefty channel lineup.

Channel lineup

Before you sign your TV life away to any cable package, know which channels you’re getting. While standards like ESPN, Food Network, and MTV are available on most plans, availability starts to vary when you get into second-tier channels like Disney XD, ESPNews, and the SEC Network.

Internet speed

There’s a lot that goes into how fast your internet runs (we’ve got a complete guide on that), but your download and upload speeds work as a general guideline.

We recommend getting an internet plan with at least 100 Mbps download speed and 10 Mbps upload speed. If you’re the only one at home, you can probably get away with less, but you’ll start noticing slowing if you have many devices connected to the internet. If you have a family or work from home, shoot for faster speeds like 200 Mbps download and 20 Mbps upload—or more if it’s in your budget. And be sure you get unlimited data with your internet plan, or else you’ll have to be careful not to accrue overage charges.

Find the best TV and internet deals near you

There are some great cable and Wi-Fi deals out there if you know what to look for. But these plans are all restricted to areas where the providers offer service. You’ll need to know which TV and internet providers can get you connected before you sign up.

Enter your zip code below, and we’ll take you to a list of the major TV and internet providers in your area. Let’s get crackin’!

Best cable and internet deals FAQ

Who has the best internet and cable bundle?

  • Frontier Fiber 500 + YouTube TV—best internet and streaming bundle
  • Spectrum Internet Gig + TV Select Signature—best for channel add-ons
  • Xfinity 500 Mbps + Ultimate TV—best for discounts
  • WOW Internet 300 Mbps + Youtube TV—best for $100

Is it cheaper to bundle TV and internet?

Most, but not all, providers will give you a discount when you bundle TV and internet with them. Xfinity is outstandingly generous when you bundle—it gives you a $20 per month discount on every service after the first one. You can read our review of Xfinity’s 500 Mbps + Ultimate TV bundle above.

What is the cheapest TV and internet package?

You can get TV and internet packages starting at $30 per month, but we wouldn’t recommend any of those bundles. With prices that low, the TV package is only a selection of local channels. You can get local media for less cash with a digital antenna.

Who offers cable and internet packages without an annual contract or term agreement?

Optimum, Astound, Spectrum, and Verizon Fios all offer cable TV and internet packages without annual contracts.

Do I have to get cable TV with internet?

Most internet providers offer internet packages without cable TV—and some internet providers don’t have TV options at all. To learn more about how to get internet without cable or a phone line (and see the cheapest prices), check out our standalone internet FAQ.

Why you should trust us

We researched over 350 TV and internet packages from major providers to find the best deals. We factored in price, availability, channel lineup, video quality, internet speeds, data caps, reliability, and sign-up incentives.

If you’d like to know more about our methodologies, head over to our How We Rank page.

Related articles

  • Best TV Providers
  • Best Streaming Deals: Disney+, Hulu, and More

The post How To Watch the 2025 CFL Season appeared first on CableTV.com.

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change. CableTV.com utilizes paid Amazon links. See full disclaimer for details.

The Canadian Football League (CFL) features eight teams battling from June to November for a chance to win the coveted Grey Cup. This season, stateside viewers can watch 34 regular-season games on CBS Sports Network. All remaining matchups will stream for free on CFL+.

Hulu + Live TV is the MVP service for watching the CFL because it has CBS Sports Network and many other channels for watching NFL and UFL games. The live TV streaming service also includes unlimited DVR storage and access to ESPN+ and Disney+ at no extra cost.

Our TV scouts have your full CFL viewing report below, including a closer look at CFL channels and key dates.

Jump to:

  • CFL channels
  • CFL TV schedule
  • Best CFL TV providers
  • Watch the CFL for free

Score the best CFL TV plan!

Enter your zip code to see your area’s top-ranked TV providers.

What channels show CFL games?

During the 2025 CFL season, you can watch games on CBS Sports Network and CFL+ in the U.S. This is the third year of the CFL’s broadcasting agreement with CBS Sports, but, unfortunately, no games will air on the main CBS Television Network.

For Canadian viewers, all CFL games air across TSN’s channels—including select Canadian French–language coverage on RDS and RDS2.

Want radio coverage? You can listen to every CFL game on SiriusXM satellite radio, with most games streaming on Canada Talks (ch. 167).

2025 CFL TV schedule: Key events and channels

From the CFL Draft in April to the Grey Cup championship in November, there’s loads of CFL action to observe each year. Below is a list of the most prominent CFL events this season, but you’ll want to check out the official CFL schedule for specific matchups and game times.

Event Start date U.S. channels Canada channels
2025 CFL Draft April 29, 2025 N/A TSN, RDS, TSN+
CFL Preseason May 19, 2025 CFL+ TSN, RDS, CFL+
CFL Opening Week June 5, 2025 CBSSN, CFL+ TSN, RDS
CFL Division Semifinals Nov. 1, 2025 CFL+ TSN, RDS
CFL Division Finals Nov. 8, 2025 CFL+ TSN, RDS
112th Grey Cup Nov. 16, 2025 CFL+ TSN, RDS

Data effective as of post date.

Best TV providers for CFL games

  • Editor’s Choice: Hulu + Live TV ($81.99–$95.99/mo.)
  • Cheapest: CFL+ (Free)
  • Best Cable or Satellite Provider: DIRECTV ($89.99–$169.99/mo.)

Don’t miss a single kickoff!

Want the most football action this season? Enter your zip code below to see what TV providers are available in your area.

Editor’s Choice: Hulu + Live TV

Editorial rating (4/5)
Price:
$81.99–$95.99/mo.
CFL channels:
CBS Sports Network
Features:
Unlimited cloud DVR storage for 9 mos.
View Plans for Hulu
Read Hulu + Live TV review

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Pros

  • Unlimited cloud DVR (for 9 mos.)
  • ESPN+ and Disney+ bundle included

Cons

  • Small sports channel lineup
  • Only 2 simultaneous streams allowed

Hulu + Live TV is the best TV provider for watching the CFL because it’s one of the easiest ways to get CBS Sports Network.

With ESPN+ incorporated into Hulu + Live TV at no extra cost, you’ll get access to many other sports leagues in one place. That’s hard-to-find convenience, as sports leagues scatter games across various channels and streaming services.

If your football fandom extends beyond the CFL, Hulu + Live TV has all the essential channels for watching NFL, UFL, and NCAA college football games. After all, the ESPN channels alone are home to Monday Night Football matchups and over 40 college bowl games. ESPN2 even airs the Women’s Football Alliance (WFA) Pro National Championship game each summer.

With all that coverage, we’re happy to report that Hulu + Live TV also has unlimited cloud DVR storage space—a vital feature for any sports fan. The DVR allows you to record and hold onto any game, series, or movie for up to nine months.

View Hulu + Live TV Plans

Cheapest: CFL+

Editorial rating (2.5/5)
Price:
Free
CFL content:
Every CFL game not airing on CBS Sports Network
Features:
40+ regular-season games and every CFL playoff match
Watch Now

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Pros

  • Exclusive CFL games
  • Free access

Cons

  • On-demand access for only 48 hours
  • Limited device compatibility

It’s a no-brainer that you’ll need CFL+ to watch most CFL games this season. Introduced in 2023, the streaming platform is completely free and shows CFL on TSN broadcasts. But it has many limitations.

The first notable downside to CFL+ is that it’s accessible only on desktop and mobile devices using a web browser. In other words, don’t expect to find CFL+ on streaming devices like Amazon Fire TV, Apple TV, and Roku. But you can use Apple AirPlay to cast games onto your smart TV.

Even with access to CFL+, it’s a pretty bare-bones experience. On-demand replays expire after 48 hours (it’s better than nothing like last season), and there aren’t any studio shows or behind-the-scenes programs to enjoy when games aren’t on. You’ll want to bookmark the CFL’s YouTube channel for extra content.

Watch CFL+

Best Cable or Satellite Provider: DIRECTV

Editorial rating (4.1/5)
Price:
$89.99–$169.99/mo.*
CFL channels:
CBS Sports Network
NFL channels:
ABC, CBS, ESPN, FOX, NBC, and NFL Network
Features:
200 hr. DVR included
View Plans for DIRECTV
Read DIRECTV review

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change. See full disclaimer for details.

Pros

  • Over 20 basic sports channels
  • Wide regional sports network (RSN) availability

Cons

  • Expensive plans
  • 2-yr. contract for new DIRECTV customers
  • No NFL Sunday Ticket anymore

DIRECTV provides a robust TV experience for fans of Canadian and American football. The satellite service carries CBS Sports Network for CFL action, plus key NFL and UFL channels.

Beyond football, DIRECTV is a huge touchdown for sports fans because it offers most regional sports networks and out-of-network packages. That makes watching baseball, basketball, and hockey much more accessible, regardless of location.

In the long run, we recommend DIRECTV only to the most committed sports fans. There are many sports channels and packages to admire on DIRECTV. But Canadian football fans will still need internet access to get complete CFL coverage through CFL+.

View DIRECTV Plans

How can I watch the CFL for free?

Fortunately, the best part about the CFL’s latest broadcast plan is that viewers not based in Canada can watch many games for free. CFL+ streams select preseason games and over 40 regular-season matchups for free.

The only games U.S. spectators can’t watch for free are the ones that air on CBS Sports Network. But services like DIRECTV and Fubo usually offer free trials that allow you to access CBS Sports Network for a limited time without paying.

How can I watch the CFL in the US?

To watch CFL games in the U.S., you’ll need a TV plan that includes CBS Sports Network. You’ll also need online access to the free CFL+ streaming platform.

Hulu + Live TV is our favorite TV provider for watching the CFL because it has CBS Sports Network and includes ESPN+ for added sports coverage. It also has unlimited cloud DVR storage and comes bundled with Disney+ for bonus entertainment.

If streaming TV is not for you, we recommend DIRECTV and its massive channel lineups. The satellite service comes at a higher cost and includes a two-year contract, but you’ll get CBS Sports Network alongside other crucial sports channels. You’ll still need internet access for CFL+ to round out your CFL coverage, but you can explore some internet options in our DIRECTV Internet guide.

How to watch the CFL FAQ

Is CFL Game Pass available in the US?

No, CFL Game Pass no longer exists. But its successor, CFL+, is available in the U.S. and other countries outside of Canada.

Can I watch the CFL online?

Yes, you can watch CFL games on CFL+ and any live TV streaming service that carries CBS Sports Network. We recommend Hulu + Live TV because it has CBS Sports Network and includes ESPN+ for additional football coverage.

Are any CFL preseason games on TV?

Yes, select CFL preseason games stream on CFL+. In Canada, TSN and RDS also show preseason matchups.

Where can I watch the CFL in Canada?

If you’re located in Canada, you can watch English-language CFL coverage across TSN’s five channels. Select games with Canadian French–language commentary air on RDS and RDS2.

Why you should trust us

Our sports experts examined the CFL broadcast schedule to see which channels air games this season. We then spent over eight hours researching and testing TV providers to determine the best ways to watch every game. Channel offerings, pricing, and ease of use were key factors when deciding our provider recommendations.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!
